bug.cf_doc_type: If docs needed, set a value

long_desc.thetext: Fedora has diverged from upstream with respect to its security class / access vector definitions. There are two lingering remnants of prior Fedora kernel experiments (ptrace_child in class process and compromise_kernel in class capability2) that don't seem to exist anymore even in the Fedora kernels and were never upstream, there is an "epolwakeup" (sic) in class capability2 which was never the upstream name (it was "epollwakeup" originally and later renamed to "block_suspend" to match the capability name change, so now you have the same capability twice and are displacing all of the subsequent capability values, which will get remapped correctly by the kernel but is creating extra work for no benefit).
This removal might be causing this: Upgrading : selinux-policy-targeted-3.13.1-202.fc25.noarch 18/57 Failed to resolve permission compromise_kernel Failed to resolve permission compromise_kernel
This bug appears to have been reported against 'rawhide' during the Fedora 25 development cycle. Changing version to '25'.

selinux-policy-3.13.1-208.fc25 has been pushed to the Fedora 25 testing repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report. See https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:Updates_Testing for instructions on how to install test updates. You can provide feedback for this update here: https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2016-662487f8f1
selinux-policy-3.13.1-208.fc25 has been pushed to the Fedora 25 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.

It appears that this update did remove "ptrace_child" and "compromise_kernel" but kept "epolwakeup" in class capability2 (just moved to the end). Given the libsepol change to warn instead of fail if a permission is not resolved, it should be possible to also remove this one unless I am missing something.
